bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1921

div1.p: Hanson reports on yellow fever work in Peru and comments on his employees, interpersonal issues, funding, and problems with steamship companies.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1921
div1.opener:
Ministerio de Fomento
---------
DIRECCION DE SALUBRIDAD PÚBLICA
---------
Chiclayo, Peru. May 20, 1921.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Some time ago I wrote you about the organization here
etc. Now in order to give you an idea of how things are going I am going to send
you copies of my last letters to the Salubridad and to The International Health
Board. As you will see the fever has presented itself in Trujillp, and other
points in the Department of Libertad. This has not been on account of lack of
efficiency in the work of Dr. Mendoza in the Province of Pacasmayo, but due to
the inefficiency of the cordon and the lack of efficient work in Trujillo. As is
always the case when you intrust a thing of this kind to people who have had no
previous experience they simply do not know how to do, or how important it is.

Mr. Rose notified me that Corrigan and Pickett were coming, which sure
is a good thing. They will furnish just the extra supervision needed for Libertad.
Seeley is working hard here and I think he will make good. I am surprised though
to nitice that he has a great deal more difficulty with the language than I ex-
pected that he would have.

In regard to Seeley I wish you would let me know just what the agreement
was which you made with him, in regard to salary. He seems to have the impression
that he is to have the same rate that Corrigan and Pickett had last year. While I
think he will make good I do not think that he is in the same class as the other
two. He seems to be thoroughly impressed with the size of the job which we have
before us.

In Libertad I have both Machado and Ramirez, Richardson was left in
Callao to help Wrightson there. By the way I suppose you have heard that Wright-
son has been named in place of Cardenas, and I am glad of it. Old Cardenas was
trying to queer my game right up to h the last, but it seems the Minister of
Fomento and Wrightson kept him from doing it, according to what Ramirez said.
It seems the President has given pretty strict orders for them to attend to my
requests. Still there a few matters which I may not be able to settle without
personally going to Lima. If I can get a boat so as not to be gone to long I
shall go to Lima after I have gone over the work with Corrigan and Pickett in
Libertad and have otulined where and what they are to do.

When I wnent to Trujillo I took Reyes with me. He has developed wonder-
fully, and I am not so sure but what he is the best of the whole bunch at the
present time. I have used him as general supervising inspector before Seeley
came, and with very good results.

I am still having difficulties with the steamship companies, they
have adopted a ridiculous proceedure, refusing even to stop to either take or
discharge mail or freight. There is no logical basis for that kind of a pro-
ceedure, and is the means of causing a lot of predjudice against the campaign.

From Mr. Rose's letter I notice that you have had a conference with
him. So far I have only received Lp 1000.0.00 from the Government for the work
in this Department, and have paid all the expenses of the Pacasmayo campaign
with the Rockefeller funds.
Wit all kinds of good wishes (and kindly introduce me to Laura)

closer.seg:
Ps.
Martha complains that Daddy does not come home. She tells the people in the
Hotel she is going to take a big boat and go see Daddy.
